heading.title: PART 11 SERVICE OF DOCUMENTS OUTSIDE AUSTRALIA AND SERVICE OF EXTERNAL PROCESS [rr 11.1–11.17]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: PART 11 SERVICE OF DOCUMENTS OUTSIDE AUSTRALIA AND SERVICE OF EXTERNAL PROCESS [rr 11.1–11.17]

leg:heading.title: SERVICE OF DOCUMENTS OUTSIDE AUSTRALIA AND SERVICE OF EXTERNAL PROCESS [rr 11.1–11.17]

p.text: [Pt 11 insrt Amendment 10 of 2006 r 2 and Sch 1[4], effective 7 July 2006]

row.entry: This Division sets out the circumstances in which service of documents outside Australia is permissible.

entry.emph: Division 2 — Service outside Australia in accordance with Attorney-General’s arrangements — Rules 11.9 –11.12

row.entry: This Division governs the service of documents outside Australia in countries which are signatories to international conventions with respect to the service of documents in that country.

entry.emph: Division 3 — Service of external process — Rules 11.13 –11.17

row.entry: These rules govern NSW service of process concerning court proceedings outside NSW.
This Part only applies to proceedings in the Supreme Court: see r 1.5 and Sch 1.

The rules in Divs 1 and 2 of this Part, and the related Sch 6 of the UCPR, are based on the former SCR Pt 10. Both the rules and Sch 6 are virtually identical with the former SCR Pt 10. The rules in Div 3 are based on the former SCR Pt 57.
A cause of action arising in NSW — Sch 6(a) ‥ [11.2.5]
Breach of contract in NSW — Sch 6(b) ‥ [11.2.10]
Cases for service of originating process ‥ [r 11.2]
Contract governed by the law of NSW — Sch 6(c)(iii) ‥ [11.2.30]
Contract made by or through an agent in NSW — Sch 6(c)(ii) ‥ [11.2.25]
Criterion for leave to proceed — arguable case ‥ [11.4.10]
Defendant domiciled or ordinarily resident in NSW — Sch 6(g) ‥ [11.2.45]
Discretion to refuse leave to proceed ‥ [11.4.15]
Joinder of a non-resident party — Sch 6(i) ‥ [11.2.55]
Leave for plaintiff to proceed where no appearance by defendant ‥ [r 11.4]
Multilateral treaty for judicial assistance — Hague Convention on service abroad ‥ [11.13.7]
Notice to the defendant served outside Australia ‥ [r 11.3]
Proceedings for contribution or indemnity — Sch 6(f) ‥ [11.2.40]
Service of documents other than originating process ‥ [r 11.5]
Service of originating process not authorised by the rules ‥ [11.7.5]
Service of originating process in a foreign country ‥ [11.6.5]
Service under international convention — how effected ‥ [r 11.10] –[r 11.11]
Treaties for judicial assistance in relation to foreign proceedings ‥ [11.13.10]

p.text: This Part applies to proceedings in the Supreme Court.
For the purposes of this Part, a reference to Australia includes a reference to the external Territories.
Legislation cited in [11.1.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 1.5.

The service rules in Pt 11 apply only to the Supreme Court, notwithstanding the more general provisions in UCPR r 1.5 : Studorp Ltd v Robinson [2012] NSWCA 382; BC201210606 (Dust Diseases Tribunal proceedings could not be served outside Australia).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 11.2] r 11.2 Cases for service of originating process (cf SCR Part 10, rule 1A)

leg:heading.title: Cases for service of originating process (cf SCR Part 10, rule 1A)

p.text: Originating process may be served outside Australia in the circumstances referred to in Schedule 6 .
This rule extends to originating process to be served outside Australia in accordance with the Hague Convention.
[subr (2) insrt Amendment 27 of 2009 Sch 1[4], effective 10 July 2009]

level.toc-caption: [11.2.5] A cause of action arising in NSW — Sch 6(a)

p.text: Legislation cited in [11.2.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 Sch 6(a).
(NSW) Commercial Arbitration Act 2010 s 35.

heading.title: A cause of action arising in NSW — Sch 6(a)

p.text: “Cause of action” in Sch 6 should not be given a narrow scope and may extend to new sources of legal rights including, for example, an estoppel claim: News Corp Ltd v Lenfest Communications Inc (1996) 21 ACSR 553; BC9604395 . The particular act or omission giving rise to the plaintiff’s substantial “cause of complaint” must take place within the jurisdiction. But it is not necessary that the whole of the events relied upon have occurred within the jurisdiction: Distillers Co (Bio-Chemicals) Ltd v Thompson [1971] AC 458; [1971] 1 NSWLR 83 (Distillers case); Jacobs v Australian Abrasives Pty Ltd [1971] Tas SR 92 ; My v Toyota Motor Co Ltd [1977] 2 NZLR 113 ; Vaughan v Weldon (1874) LR 10 CP 47; Jackson v Spittall (1870) LR 5 CP 542; Chidzey v Breckler [1920] VLR 558 ; WFM Motors Pty Ltd v Maydwell (NSWSC, Bryson J, 23 April 1993, unreported, BC9301698) (demand made under a guarantee). See also Lazarus v Thompson (1881) Tarl 13; Menzies v Williams (1893) 10 WN (NSW) 13. For example, it is sufficient that the facts giving rise to the cause of action occur within the jurisdiction even though the cause of action itself may derive from legislation of another jurisdiction: Nominal Defendant v Motor Vehicle Insurance Trust of Western Australia [1983] 3 NSWLR 309.

The place where damage occurs may sometimes provide an indication as to the place where the cause of action arose. This is particularly so where, as in the Distillers case, above, and in Castree v ER Squibb and Sons Ltd [1980] 2 All ER 589; [1980] 1 WLR 1248 , it is accompanied by a breach of duty within the jurisdiction, for example, a failure to warn about the risks associated with use of a product. See also Diamond v Bank of London & Montreal Ltd [1979] QB 333; [1979] 1 All ER 561; [1979] 2 WLR 228 ; Cordoba Shipping Co Ltd v National State Bank [1984] 2 Lloyd’s Rep 91 (both cases concerned with statements made outside, but causing loss within, the jurisdiction.) However, the mere fact that damage has occurred within the jurisdiction is not alone sufficient to show that the cause of action itself arose within the jurisdiction: George Monro Ltd v American Cyanamid & Chemical Corp [1944] 1 KB 432; [1944] 1 All ER 386 (tortious claim relating to goods purchased and delivered under a foreign contract and re-supplied within the jurisdiction — the tortious act itself must have occurred within the jurisdiction); Buttigeig v Universal Terminal and Stevedoring Corp [1972] VR 626 (claim arising from manner in which cargo was loaded in foreign port — no local tort); Hall v Australian Capital Territory Electricity Authority [1980] 2 NSWLR 26; (1980) 31 ALR 557 (tortious claim relating to a fire that crossed state border); contrast Distillers Co (Bio-Chemicals) Ltd v Thompson [1971] AC 458; [1971] 1 NSWLR 83 (tort claim relating to foreign manufactured pharmaceutical but based on failure to warn within the jurisdiction).

A cause of action by a liquidator to set aside a preferential payment made by a company resident in NSW is one which arises within the State and within the meaning of the rule, notwithstanding that the payment is made to a foreign creditor: Staff Engineered Membranes Pty Ltd (in liq) v Synflex Industries (International) Inc [1984] 2 NSWLR 116 ; New Cap Reinsurance Corp Ltd (in liq) v Renaissance Reinsurance Ltd (2002) 192 ALR 601; [2002] NSWSC 856; BC200205531 .

A foreign arbitral award made in pursuance of an arbitration agreement in a country other than Australia to which the United Nations Convention on the Recognition and Enforcement of Foreign Arbitral Awards 1958 applies, may found “a cause of action arising in the state” so as to authorise service outside Australia of an application for leave (under s 35 of the Commercial Arbitration Act 2010 (NSW)) to enforce the award in the same manner as a judgment of the court to the same effect: Brali v Hyundai Corp (1988) 15 NSWLR 734; 84 ALR 176 at 743 .

level.toc-caption: [11.2.10] Breach of contract in NSW — Sch 6(b)

p.text: Legislation cited in [11.2.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 Sch 6(b).

heading.title: Breach of contract in NSW — Sch 6(b)

p.text: In determining where a breach of contract has occurred, one must look at the substance of the conduct which is alleged to constitute the breach. For example, where the plaintiff alleges that the defendant has, in effect, repudiated his or her contractual obligations and relies upon the content of a letter, cable, telex or telephone conversation as recording that repudiation, then the relevant breach will ordinarily be held to have occurred at the place from which the message was sent. This is irrespective of the proper law governing the contract: Stanley Kerr Holdings Pty Ltd v Gibor Textile Enterprises Ltd [1978] 2 NSWLR 372 ; Safran v Chani (1970) 70 SR (NSW) 146; 91 WN (NSW) 186; Martin v Stout [1925] AC 359 at 368 . On the other hand, where the breach relied upon is the improper giving of notice, then ordinarily the breach occurs at the place where the notice is actually received: Crawford Fitting Co v Sydney Valve & Fitting Pty Ltd (NSWCA, Glass, Mahoney and Priestley JJA, 14407/85, 24 June 1986, unreported, BC8600897).

Where a foreign seller pursuant to a cif contract fails to ship the goods, the breach arises at the place of shipment, notwithstanding that the shipping documents themselves are required to be tendered within the jurisdiction: Johnson v Taylor Bros & Co Ltd [1920] AC 144 . Similarly, where a shipper under a cif contract ships goods which are unfit, the breach occurs at the place of delivery on board ship, and not at the point where they actually come into the possession of the buyer: Amalgamated Chemicals Ltd v Montedison Spa (NSWSC, Roden J, 9399/84, 26 August 1985, unreported, BC8500583).

The opposite position applies where actual delivery of the goods is required to be made within the jurisdiction: Hampstead Meats Pty Ltd v Emerson and Yates Pty Ltd [1967] SASR 109 . Where the breach alleged is non-payment of money due under the contract, the breach occurs at the place where payment is due; that is, the place where the parties either expressly or impliedly intended that payment should be made: Haldane v Johnson (1853) 8 Exch 689; 155 ER 1529 ; Shallay Holdings Pty Ltd v Griffith Co-op Society Ltd [1983] 1 VR 760; (1982) 48 ALR 304 ; WFM Motors Pty Ltd v Maydwell (NSWSC, Bryson J, 23 April 1993, unreported, BC9301698) (failure to pay moneys demanded under a guarantee — place of demand is place of payment). As to the position where a creditor is entitled to nominate a place for payment but fails to do so, see BP Australia Ltd v Wales [1982] Qd R 386 . Kim Michael Productions Pty Ltd v Tropical Islands Management Ltd [2010] NSWSC 269; BC201002171 at [53] (non-payment breach occurred in NSW — but NSW “clearly” inappropriate — proceedings stayed: [95]. When the breach is based upon the failure to notify, the breach will occur in the place when notification should have occurred: News Corp Ltd v Lenfest Communications Inc (1996) 21 ACSR 553; BC9604395 .
Legislation cited in [11.2.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 Sch 6(c).
(NSW) Law Reform (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 1946 s 5(1)(c).

Whether or not a contract is governed by the law of the State will be determined by the private international law rules for ascertaining the proper law of a contract, as to which see Akai Pty Ltd v People’s Insurance Co Ltd (1996) 188 CLR 418; 141 ALR 374; [1996] HCA 39; BC9606281 ; News Corp Ltd v Lenfest Communications Inc (1996) 21 ACSR 553; BC9604395 . The decided cases appear to have accorded the word “contract” a wide meaning so as to include not only consensual contracts but also “implied, fictitious or constructive contracts” for which the old forms of actions of assumpsit or indebitatus would have been available: Gosper v Sawyer (1985) 160 CLR 548; 58 ALR 13; BC8501121 ; Sawyer v Shell Refining (Aust) Pty Ltd [1984] 2 NSWLR 262 . Thus, proceedings upon a contract include proceedings upon a judgment (Adcock v Aarons (1903) 5 WALR 140 ; followed in Nominal Defendant v Motor Vehicle Insurance Trust of Western Australia [1983] 3 NSWLR 309 ); proceedings to recover municipal rates (Belyando Shire Council v Rivers [1908] QWN 17; (1908) 2 QJPR 47 ); or stamp duty (Victoria v Hansen [1960] VR 582; (1959) 2 FLR 335 ); or federal income tax (Chenoweth v Summers [1941] ALR (CN) 364); and proceedings to recover money due upon an account stated (Halliday v Ryan [1938] ALR 200 ; McFee Engineering Pty Ltd (in liq) v CBS Constructions Pty Ltd (1980) 28 ALR 339 at 348; 44 FLR 340 ); and upon a quantum meruit for work done (Earthworks and Quarries Ltd v FT Eastment & Sons Pty Ltd [1966] VR 24; (1965) 8 FLR 32 ); but not a claim for contribution under the s 5(1)(c) of the Law Reform (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 1946 (Gilchrist v Dean [1960] VR 266; (1958) 2 FLR 175 ); or for an indemnity under the s 64 of the Workers’ Compensation Act 1926: Wilson Electric Transformer Co Pty Ltd v Electricity Commission of New South Wales [1968] VR 330; (1968) 12 FLR 314 . But see [11.2.40] . Proceedings for a declaration that a contract has been frustrated would fall within the expression “where the subject matter of the proceedings is a contract”: cf BP Exploration Co (Libya) Ltd v Hunt [1976] 3 All ER 879 at 885; [1976] 1 WLR 788 at 795 . The term “contract” will not ordinarily include a discretionary trust. At least not unless the trustees have admitted that they hold part of the trust fund for a particular beneficiary: Gosper v Sawyer (1985) 160 CLR 548; 58 ALR 13; BC8501121 .
Legislation cited in [11.2.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 Sch 6(c)(i).

The place where the contract was made is to be determined in accordance with the ordinary principles. The fact that the contract contains a provision which deems the contract to have been made in a particular place, does not preclude an inquiry as to where it was in fact made: Sheldon Pallet Manufacturing Co Pty Ltd v New Zealand Forest Products [1975] 1 NSWLR 141 at 147 ; Oceanic Sun Line Special Shipping Co Inc v Fay (1988) 165 CLR 197; 79 ALR 9; BC8802600 (contract for a sea voyage in Greece held to have been made in Sydney where the deposit was paid). A contract that was first made within, and later varied outside, the State is still made within the jurisdiction: Entores Ltd v Miles Far East Corp [1955] 2 QB 327.

Where the contract is contained in a formal instrument, the place of its execution is the place where it is made. However, if the contract is executed by the parties in different places, the place of the last execution is the place where it is made: Inland Revenue Cmr v Muller & Co Margarine Ltd [1901] AC 217 at 218, 223 and 225 .

The general position is that acceptance is not effective until communicated to the offeror. Therefore, the place where the acceptance is received is the place where the contract is made. The general position is subject to an exception in the case of postal acceptance. When offer and acceptance are communicated by post (Dunlop v Higgins (1848) 1 HL Cas 381 ; Adams v Lindsell (1818) 1 B & Ald 681; 106 ER 250; Henthorne v Frazer [1872] LR 7 Ch App 587 at 594), or by telegram (Cowen v O’Connor (1888) 2 QBD 640 at 642; Bruner v Moore [1904] 1 Ch 305 ), the contract is made at the place from which the letter or telegram of acceptance is despatched: Lewis Construction Co Pty Ltd v Tichauer Société Anonyme [1966] VR 341 ; Witt & Scott Ltd v Blumenreich [1949] NZLR 806 . This “postal acceptance” exception to the general rule (that acceptance is not effective until communicated to the offeror) is justified by reference to the inconvenient consequences which might follow if an offer could be revoked at any time until a letter of acceptance was actually received: Household Buyer & Carriage Accident Insurance Co Ltd v Grant (1879) 4 Ex D 216 at 223 . Where, however, acceptance is communicated by telex or telephone, the justification for the postal rule is inapplicable since the communication is instantaneous. In these cases, the contract is made where the acceptance is received: Brinkibon Ltd v Stanley Stahl GmbH [1983] 2 AC 34; [1982] 1 All ER 293 ; Entores Ltd v Miles Far East Corp [1955] 2 QB 327 ; Mendelsohn-Vella Co Inc v T & C Providores Pty Ltd [1981] 1 NSWLR 366 ; Express Airways v Port Augusta Air Services [1980] Qd R 543 ; Hampstead Meats Pty Ltd v Emerson and Yates Pty Ltd [1967] SASR 109 ; Diamond v Bank of London & Montreal Ltd [1979] QB 333; [1979] 1 All ER 561; [1979] 2 WLR 228 (representation made by telephone); Reese Bros Plastics Ltd v Hamon-Sobelco Australia Pty Ltd (1988) 5 BPR 11,106; BC8802280 (contract made by exchange of facsimile transmissions); cf Leach Nominees Pty Ltd v Walker Wright Pty Ltd [1986] WAR 244; (1985) 85 FLR 427 (contract made when telex confirmation delivered to public telex office).

Where the relevant contract involves an irrevocable letter of credit, the offer constituted by the letter of credit is accepted, and the contract therefore made, at the place where the letter is drawn upon: Elder Dempster Lines Ltd v Ionic Shipping Agency Inc [1968] 1 Lloyd’s Rep 529 at 535; Bank of New South Wales v Commonwealth Steel Co Ltd [1983] 1 NSWLR 69 ; Westpac Banking Corp v Commonwealth Steel Co Ltd [1983] 1 NSWLR 735 .

level.toc-caption: [11.2.25] Contract made by or through an agent in NSW — Sch 6(c)(ii)

p.text: Legislation cited in [11.2.25] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 Sch 6(c)(ii).

heading.title: Contract made by or through an agent in NSW — Sch 6(c)(ii)

p.text: Where the contract is alleged to have been made “by or through an agent”, it is not necessary that the agent actually concluded the contract with the other party. It is sufficient if the agent received orders for the principal and transmitted them to the principal for formal acceptance: National Mortgage & Agency Co of New Zealand v Gosselin (1922) 38 TLR 832 ; HC Sleigh Ltd v Barry Clarke & Co Ltd [1954] SASR 49 .

level.toc-caption: [11.2.30] Contract governed by the law of NSW — Sch 6(c)(iii)

p.text: Legislation cited in [11.2.30] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 Sch 6(c)(iii).

heading.title: Contract governed by the law of NSW — Sch 6(c)(iii)

p.text: Where the contract, or a particular obligation arising under it, is subject to more than one proper law, there is some uncertainty as to whether or not leave to effect service outside the jurisdiction can be granted under the rules: cf Weckstrom v Hyson [1966] VR 277 at 282 ; The Armar [1981] 1 All ER 498 at 505 .
Legislation cited in [11.2.32] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Competition and Consumer Act 2010 s 52.
(NSW) Fair Trading Act 1987 s 42.

A tort is committed in New South Wales if that is the place where the defendant’s actionable conduct occurred in relation to the plaintiff: Distillers Co (Bio-Chemicals) Ltd v Thompson [1971] AC 458 at 468; [1971] 1 NSWLR 83 ; Voth v Manildra Flour Mills Pty Ltd (1990) 171 CLR 538 at 566–70; 97 ALR 124; BC9002894 ; D'Ath v TNT Aust Pty Ltd [1992] 1 Qd R 369 at 375–8 ; Sydbank Soenderjyllad A/S v Banneron Holdings Pty Ltd (1996) 68 FCR 539; 149 ALR 134; BC9604067 . For example, if the claim is in negligence the relevant place of the tort is where the material breach of duty occurred: George Monro Ltd v American Cyanamid & Chemical Corp [1944] 1 KB 432 at 441 ; [1944] 1 All ER 386 at 390 . The mere fact that some damage occurs in the jurisdiction is not sufficient to make it the place where the tort was committed: Buttigeig v Universal Terminal and Stevedoring Corp [1972] VR 626 ; MacGregor v Application des Gaz [1976] Qd R 175 ; Hall v Australian Capital Territory Electricity Authority [1980] 2 NSWLR 26; (1980) 31 ALR 557 . Where the claim involves conduct that occurs partly outside the jurisdiction (eg, the manufacture or design of a defective product) and partly within (eg, an alleged “failure to warn” about the use of the product within the jurisdiction) characterisation of the place the tort was committed may involve an impressionistic assessment: Distillers Co (Bio-Chemicals) Ltd v Thompson [1971] AC 458 at 468; [1971] 1 NSWLR 83 ; D'Ath v TNT Aust Pty Ltd [1992] 1 Qd R 369 . Some examples illustrate the assessment for different causes of action:

Conspiracy: The tort is committed within the jurisdiction if that is the place where the “overt acts” occur — even if the preceding agreement is entered into by foreign nationals outside the jurisdiction: Enzacor Technology Pty Ltd v Ko Sai Ying [1992] VSC 6929; BC9304159 .

Defamation: Defamatory publication occurs where the impugned statement is communicated: Berezovsky v Michaels [2000] 2 All ER 986; [2000] 1 WLR 1004 ; Bata v Bata [1948] WN 336; Dow Jones & Co Inc v Gutnick (2002) 210 CLR 575 at 600 607, 610 ; 194 ALR 433 at 440 445, 448; 77 ALJR 255 at 260 264, 265; [2002] HCA 56; BC200207411 at [25], [46], [56] (defamatory internet material – accessed at a computer terminal in Victoria – tort of defamation committed in Victoria).

Fraudulent/negligent misrepresentation: Statements made by electronic transmission are committed where they are received or read and acted upon, and not at the place from which they are sent: Diamond v Bank of London & Montreal Ltd [1979] QB 333 at 346; [1979] 1 All ER 561 at 564; [1979] 2 WLR 228 at 234 (fraudulent or negligent misrepresentation made by telephone and telex from Bahamas to England — misrepresentation received and acted on in England — tort committed in England).

Misleading and deceptive conduct: Conflicting views have been expressed as to whether claims of misleading and deceptive conduct under s 52 of the Trade Practices Act 1974 and s 42 of the Fair Trading Act 1987 (now s 18 of the Australian Consumer Law, see Competition and Consumer Act 2010 Sch 2 s 18) constitute a tort: Commonwealth Bank of Australia v White [1999] 2 VR 681; [1999] VSC 262; BC9904419 (the claim involves a tort); Jonstan Pty Ltd v Nicholson (2003) 58 NSWLR 223; 184 FLR 247; [2003] NSWSC 500; BC200303036 ; contrast Williams v Society of Lloyd's [1994] 1 VR 274 at 311–12 ; Borch v Answer Products Inc [2000] QSC 379; BC200006441 ; Lukey v Corporate Investment Australia Funds Management Pty Ltd [2005] FCA 298; BC200501356 .

Professional negligence: Where the tort involves acts or omissions by professional advisers professional the place of the tort is where the conduct giving rise to the cause of complaint was committed: Voth v Manildra Flour Mills Pty Ltd (1990) 171 CLR 538 at 569 ; 97 ALR 124 at 144; BC9002894 (US accountants failed advise on tax liability — incorrect advice — tort committed in US).
Legislation cited in [11.2.35] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 Sch 6(e).

Damage for the purpose of this paragraph is not confined to the immediate physical injury or loss suffered when the cause of action first accrued: Brix-Neilsen v Oceaneering Australia Pty Ltd [1982] 2 NSWLR 173 ; Challenor v Douglas [1983] 2 NSWLR 405 ; Flaherty v Girgis 63 ALR 466; (1985) 4 NSWLR 248 at 266E; 63 ALR 466 ; McKinnon v Freeway Holdings (1968) Pty Ltd [1979] ACLD 409. If the plaintiff, although first injured outside the State, thereafter suffers damage within the State, for example, by a consequential loss of income or incurring medical expenditure consequent upon physical injury, then service of process outside the jurisdiction is authorised: McKinnon , above; Brix-Neilsen , above; Challenor , above; Flaherty v Girgis , above. Similarly, damages for the purposes of this paragraph may include a liability for financial loss in respect of repairs to property, even where both the damage and the repairs occurred outside the state: Darrell Lea Chocolate Shops Pty Ltd v Spanish Polish Shipping Co Inc (1992) 25 NSWLR 568; Colosseum Investment Holdings Pty Ltd v Vanguard Logistics Services Pty Ltd [2005] NSWSC 803 at [40]–[50]; BC200505735 . A contribution claim, arising from a judgment of a court within the state, involves a claim for the recovery of damages under Schedule 6(e) if the judgment itself relates to tortiously caused damage: Victorian Workcover Authority v Orientstar Shipping Corp [2004] VSCA 237; BC200408811 at [16] .

level.toc-caption: [11.2.40] Proceedings for contribution or indemnity — Sch 6(f)

p.text: Legislation cited in [11.2.40] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 Sch 6(f).
(NSW) Law Reform (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 1946 s 5(1)(c).

heading.title: Proceedings for contribution or indemnity — Sch 6(f)

p.text: Whether proceedings are for contribution or indemnity is to be determined by the substance of the remedy sought, rather than by the nature of the cause of action. Accordingly, service under this paragraph is not confined to claims for contribution under statutory provisions such as s 5(1)(c) of the Law Reform (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 1946. It extends to damages claims where the nature of the damages claimed is for contribution or indemnity in relation to the claimant’s liability to a third party: Australian Iron & Steel Pty Ltd v Jumbo Scheepvaart Maatschappij (Curacao) NV (1988) 14 NSWLR 507 at 518–21 ; HIH Casualty & General Insurance Ltd v Meadows Indemnity Co Ltd (1998) 47 NSWLR 85; BC9806731 ; not following Angus & Coote Pty Ltd v Qantas Airways Ltd [1979] 2 NSWLR 398 (which was decided before the term “originating process” was defined to include proceedings on a cross-claim) and Elders IXL Ltd v Lindgren Pty Ltd (FCA, Fox J, 17 May 1988, unreported, BC8802782) (which was decided after the definitional change).

level.toc-caption: [11.2.45] Defendant domiciled or ordinarily resident in NSW — Sch 6(g)

p.text: Legislation cited in [11.2.45] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 Sch 6(g).

heading.title: Defendant domiciled or ordinarily resident in NSW — Sch 6(g)

p.text: Service is authorised under this rule to any cause of action irrespective of whether it arose within the jurisdiction and irrespective of whether service would be authorised under any other provision: Lenders v Anderson (1883) 12 QBD 50 ; Hadad v Bruce (1892) 8 TLR 409. In general, the domicile of a person is the country in which he or she has his or her permanent home (Dicey L, Dicey and Morris on Conflict of Laws, 9th ed, Sweet & Maxwell, London, 1987, Ch 8) or the country where he or she presently resides without any present intention of moving: Re Craignish [1892] 3 Ch 180 ; Huntley v Gaskell [1906] AC 56 ; Casdagli v Casdagli [1919] AC 145 . No person can at any time be without a domicile or have more than one domicile. The domicile of origin remains until a new domicile of choice has been adopted: Bell v Kennedy (1868) LR 1 Sc & Div 307; Winans v A-G [1904] AC 287 . For the purposes of the subrule, “person” includes a corporation: Williams v United States and Australasia Steamship Co (1908) 25 WN (NSW) 43. A corporation may be resident in more than one place at the same time: BHP Petroleum Pty Ltd v Oil Basins Ltd [1985] VR 725 at 740 . But the fact that a corporation could have been served within the jurisdiction does not render service outside the jurisdiction effective unless it was otherwise valid under the present rule: Eason v 3AW Broadcasting Co Pty Ltd (1985) 81 FLR 229; BC8500886 ; Ainsworth Nominees Pty Ltd v Hanrahan [1982] 2 NSWLR 823 at 825 .
Legislation cited in [11.2.50] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 Sch 6(h).

Where prospective defendants have indicated they are prepared to submit to the jurisdiction but have not nominated a place for service, leave for service outside the jurisdiction may be granted in accordance with this paragraph: British Wagon Co Ltd v Gray [1896] 1 QB 35 . Foreign plaintiffs who commence proceedings within the jurisdiction necessarily submit to any cross-claim that would operate as a defence to the claim or which otherwise arises out of the same subject matter: National Commercial Bank v Wimborne (1979) 11 NSWLR 56. The implied submission to the jurisdiction does not however extend further so as to include any cross-claim that can properly be brought irrespective of its relationship to the plaintiff’s original claim or the facts upon which it is based: Marlborough Harbour Board v Charter Travel Co Ltd (1989) 18 NSWLR 223 .

level.toc-caption: [11.2.55] Joinder of a non-resident party — Sch 6(i)

p.text: Legislation cited in [11.2.55] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 Sch 6(i).
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 22.

heading.title: Joinder of a non-resident party — Sch 6(i)

p.text: Proceedings may be “properly brought against a person served ... in the State” even where that person is a non-resident who has submitted to the jurisdiction: Derby & Co Ltd v Larsson [1976] 1 WLR 202 (cross-claim against non-resident plaintiff); The Beharty [1983] 1 Lloyd’s Rep 361 (submission to jurisdiction before commencement of proceedings); Amanuel v Alexandros Shipping Co [1986] 1 QB 464; cf John Russell & Co Ltd v Cayzer Irvine & Co Ltd [1916] 2 AC 298 . The question whether the person to be served outside Australia is “properly joined” is to be determined having regard to the ordinary practice in relation to joinder of parties within the jurisdiction. The rule permits joinder of the foreign party either as a defendant to the plaintiff’s claim or as a defendant to a cross-claim: Australian Iron & Steel Pty Ltd v Jumbo Scheepvaart Maatschappij (Curacao) NV (1988) 14 NSWLR 507 at 518 not following Elders IXL Ltd v Lindgren Pty Ltd (FCA, Fox J, 17 May 1988, unreported, BC8802782). The claim against the resident defendant must be genuine and not doomed to failure: Witted v Galbraith [1893] 1 QB 577 at 579 ; Tyne Improvement Cmrs v Armement Anversois S/A (The Brabo) [1949] AC 326 at 339, 345, 347, 349, 351 and 354; [1949] 1 All ER 294 . This requirement will not be satisfied if it appears that proceedings have been commenced merely for the purpose of facilitating or enabling an application for leave to serve the foreign defendant: Witted v Galbraith [1893] 1 QB 577 ; Tyne Improvement, above; Rossler v Hilbery [1925] Ch 250 ; Coppin v Tobler Bros Canberra Marine Centre Pty Ltd [1980] 1 NSWLR 183. The claim against the foreign defendant must also be genuine, but it is not necessary that it should be a claim as to either joint or alternative liability to the claim against the resident defendant. Rather, it is sufficient if, had the foreign defendants been residents, they could have been joined as a necessary or proper party to the proceedings: Croft v King [1893] 1 QB 419 ; Richardson v Tiver [1960] VR 578 ; Sykes v Scholfield (1884) 28 Sol Jo 477; Oesterreichische Export AG v British Indemnity Insurance Co Ltd [1914] 2 KB 747 ; Evershore Textiles Manufacturing Co Ltd v Webb [1978] Qd R 347 ; Coppin, above; Maclaine Watson & Co Private Ltd v Bing Chen [1983] 1 NSWLR 163 ; Bank of New South Wales v Commonwealth Steel Co Ltd [1983] 1 NSWLR 69 ; Westpac Banking Corp v Commonwealth Steel Co Ltd [1983] 1 NSWLR 735; not following Angus & Coote Pty Ltd v Qantas Airways Ltd [1979] 2 NSWLR 398 . It may be that this paragraph is wide enough to cover the case of a defendant joining a third party as a cross-defendant pursuant to CPA s 22 : Australian Iron & Steel , above, at 518; but cf Elders IXL , above. Where proceedings are brought against a person for selling goods in breach of a patent, if the ultimate supplier has procured the sales he also is liable and may be served under this paragraph: Best Australia Ltd v Aquagas Marketing Pty (1988) 83 ALR 217; 12 IPR 143 . The constitutional validity of the equivalent provision in the former rules has been upheld in Coppin , above; Maclaine Watson , above; and Flaherty v Girgis (1985) 4 NSWLR 248; 63 ALR 466 .
Legislation cited in [11.2.60] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 Sch 6(j).

The property within the state must be the subject matter of the proceedings. It is not sufficient that the relief claimed in the proceedings relates indirectly to the property. The general nature of the distinction between the cases that fall within the subrules and those that do not can be perceived in the decided cases, although it must be conceded that not all of them are possible to reconcile convincingly.

An action to enforce a deed to convey property falls within the subrule: Agnew v Usher (1884) 14 QBD 78 ; Jones v Flower (1904) 24 NZLR 447 . So also does a proceeding to appoint a manager of the property of a foreign defendant who, through mental infirmity, is incapable of managing his or her affairs in the jurisdiction: Maclaine Watson & Co Private Ltd v Bing Chen [1983] 1 NSWLR 163 at 168, 169 ; MS v ES [1983] 3 NSWLR 199 at 203 . An action for recovery of rent did not fall within the subrule: Pilkington v McArthur Trust Ltd (No 2) [1938] NZLR 564 ; Attorney-General v Drapers Co [1894] 1 IR 185 . Neither does a claim under a policy of insurance affecting the property: Muusers v SGIO (Qld) [1980] 2 NSWLR 73 ; Casey v Arnott (1876) 2 CPD 24 . So, too, actions for compensation for improvements or for breaches of a covenant to repair were outside this paragraph: Kaye v Sutherland (1887) 20 QBD 147 ; Tassell v Hallen [1892] 1 QB 321 ; William Cable & Co v Teagle Smith & Sons Ltd [1928] NZLR 427 . A claim to recover the stamp duty on a conveyance of property is not within the subrules: Victoria v Hansen [1960] VR 582; (1959) 2 FLR 335 , although a different result may follow where the duty or tax payable constitutes a charge upon the land: Shire of Yeerongpilly v Love (1906) 1 QJPR 73; Mority v Stephan (1888) 58 LT 850; but cf Kolchmann v Meurice [1903] 1 KB 534 .
Legislation cited in [11.2.65] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 24.18, Sch 6(k).
As to perpetuation of testimony, see r 24.18 of the UCPR and the accompanying annotations.
Legislation cited in [11.2.70] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 Sch 6(n).

The court may permit service in order to grant injunctive relief in respect of acts done within the jurisdiction where those acts are caused, directed or controlled by a non-resident: Dunlop Rubber Co Ltd v Dunlop [1921] 1 AC 367 . However, even where jurisdiction exists, the court retains a discretion as to whether or not to grant leave to serve outside the jurisdiction. Generally speaking, the court will not make an order unless:
there is a good arguable case: Société Generale de Paris v Dreyfus Bros (1887) 37 Ch D 215 ; Chemische Fabrik v Badische Anilin Fabriks (1904) 90 LT 733 ; Watson v Daily Record [1907] 1 KB 853 ;
the subject matter is within the jurisdiction: Kinahan v Kinahan (1890) 45 Ch D 78 ; Morocco Bound Syndicate v Harris [1895] 1 Ch 534 ;

the claim is bona fide and not merely made to bring the proceedings within this rule: Badische Anilin und Soda Fabrik v Henry Johnson & Co [1896] 1 Ch 25 ; Badische Anilin und Soda Fabrik v Henry Johnson & Co [1897] 2 Ch 322 at 345 ; De Bernales v New York Herald (1893) 52 LJQB 385; [1893] 2 QB 97;
there is a proper basis for, and a reasonable probability of, the injunction being granted: British Marine Assn v MacInnes (1886) 31 Sol Jo 95; Attorney-General v Manchester Corp [1893] 2 Ch 87 ;

there is some method of making the injunction effectual: Marshall v Marshall (1888) 38 Ch D 330 ; Kinahan v Kinahan (1890) 45 Ch D 78 at 84 ; Watson v Daily Record [1907] 1 KB 853 ; Alexander v Valentine (1908) 25 TLR 29. It is, however, sufficient that there is a reasonable ground for believing that the injunction will be efficacious at some time in the future, for instance, whenever the defendant enters the jurisdiction: Tozier v Hawkins (1885) 15 QBD 650 at 680 ; Re Burland’s Trade Mark (1889) 41 Ch D 542 .

The injunction need not be the only relief sought, but it must be part of the substantive relief claimed: Lisbon-Berlyn (Transvaal) Goldfields Co v Heddle (1884) 52 LT 796 ; Rossler v Hilbery [1925] Ch 250 . The Supreme Court does not have jurisdiction to grant injunctions to restrain apprehended trespass or nuisance in relation to real property outside New South Wales: Corvisy v Corvisy [1982] 2 NSWLR 557 .

A claim for a Mareva asset preservation order to prevent a foreign defendant from disposing of their assets within the jurisdiction is not a proceeding for an injunction in respect of which leave for service outside the jurisdiction can be granted under the present paragraph: Siskina v Distos Compania Naviera SA (The Siskina) [1979] AC 210; [1977] 3 All ER 803 ; Mercedes Benz AG v Leiduck [1996] AC 284; [1995] 3 All ER 929 (PC). This is because the jurisdiction to grant such an injunction derives from the ancillary powers of the court in relation to matters that are otherwise within its jurisdiction. A claim for a Mareva type injunction cannot be made the basis of the court’s jurisdiction: WFM Motors Pty Ltd v Maydwell (NSWSC, Bryson J, 23 April 1993, unreported, BC9301698). A doubt has been raised as to whether this paragraph extends to mandatory injunctions or is concerned only with prohibitory injunctions. See BHP Petroleum Pty Ltd v Oil Basins Ltd [1985] VR 725 at 752 .
Legislation cited in [11.2.75] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 Sch 6(w).

This paragraph is a facilitating provision which overcomes the general principle that would otherwise require the various parts of the Schedule to be read disjunctively: Matthews v Kuwait Bechtel Corp [1959] 2 QB 57 . Paragraph (w) does not authorise service of a claim where there are multiple claims and some of them do not fall within any of the enumerated paragraphs, even if there is a claim that does: Siskina v Distos Compania Naviera SA (The Siskina) [1979] AC 210 at 255; [1977] 3 All ER 803 ; WFM Motors Pty Ltd v Maydwell (NSWSC, Bryson J, 23 April 1993, unreported, BC9301698); CE Heath Underwriting & Insurance (Aust) Pty Ltd v Barden (NSWSC, Rolfe J, 50132/93, 19 October 1994, unreported, BC9403144). Accordingly, a plaintiff may not proceed against a person served outside Australia on causes of action that fall outside paragraph (w): Australian Iron & Steel Pty Ltd v Jumbo Scheepvaart Maatschappij (Curacao) NV (1988) 14 NSWLR 507 at 517–18 , citing Siskina v Distos Compania Naviera SA (The Siskina) [1979] AC 210 at 255; [1977] 3 All ER 803 ; Merpro Montassa Ltd v Conoco Special Products Inc (1991) 28 FCR 387 ; Tycoon Holdings Ltd v Trencor Jetco Inc (1992) 34 FCR 31; (1992) ATPR ¶41-183 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 11.3] r 11.3 Notice to the defendant served outside Australia (cf SCR Part 10, rule 2A)

leg:heading.title: Notice to the defendant served outside Australia (cf SCR Part 10, rule 2A)

p.text: If originating process is intended to be served on a defendant outside Australia, a notice to that effect must be included in the originating process.
This rule does not apply to originating process that is intended to be served on a defendant outside Australia in accordance with the Hague Convention.
Division 2 of Part 11A deals with the service of local judicial documents in a country (other than Australia) that is a party to the Hague Convention.
[subr (2) insrt Amendment 27 of 2009 Sch 1[5], effective 10 July 2009]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 11.4] r 11.4 Leave for plaintiff to proceed where no appearance by defendant (cf SCR Part 10, rule 2)

leg:heading.title: Leave for plaintiff to proceed where no appearance by defendant (cf SCR Part 10, rule 2)

p.text: If originating process is served on a defendant outside Australia, and the defendant does not enter an appearance, the plaintiff may not proceed against the defendant except by leave of the Supreme Court.
A motion for leave under subrule (1) may be made without serving notice of motion on the defendant.

Rule 11.8 provides for the interaction between this Division and Part 11A (which deals with service of judicial documents under the Hague Convention). See Division 3 of Part 11A in relation to default judgement in proceedings in the Supreme Court after service overseas of a local judicial document.
[r 11.4 am Amendment 27 of 2009 Sch 1[6], effective 10 July 2009]
Legislation cited in [11.4.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 UCPR Sch 6.

Leave is not required to serve proceedings outside Australia. If a foreign defendant appears, there is no requirement to obtain leave to continue the proceedings and, in any event, the defendant would be regarded as having voluntarily submitted to the jurisdiction of the court. Where the foreign defendant does not appear, no further step can be taken in the proceedings until the plaintiff obtains leave to proceed. In order to obtain that leave, the plaintiff must prove proper service on the defendant: Castagna v Conceria Pell Mec Spa (NSWCA, Mahoney P, Handley JA and Waddell AJA, 15 March 1996, unreported, BC9601018); Bulldogs Rugby League Club Ltd v Williams [2008] NSWSC 822; BC200807132 at [30] ff (personal service effected); ASIC v Sweeney (No 2) [2001] NSWSC 477; 38 ASCR 743; BC200103587 at [40] (proper service effected by substituted service); Building Insurers’ Guarantee Corporation v Eddie [2008] NSWSC 195; BC200801455 (proper service effected by substituted service). The plaintiff must also show that the proceedings come within UCPR Sch 6 : Bank of America v Bank of New York (1995) ATPR ¶41-390; News Corp Ltd v Lenfest Communications Inc (1996) 21 ACSR 553; BC9604395 ; Bulldogs Rugby League Club Ltd v Williams [2008] NSWSC 822; BC200807132 at [31] ff (sufficient evidence of submission to the jurisdiction of the courts of NSW). Proper service on an absent defendant is an essential issue in any application for leave to proceed: Castagna v Conceria Pell Mec Spa, above.

level.toc-caption: [11.4.10] Criterion for leave to proceed — arguable case

p.text: Legislation cited in [11.4.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 11.4, r 11.7, Sch 6.

heading.title: Criterion for leave to proceed — arguable case

p.text: On an application for leave under the present rule, and particularly on an application by the foreign defendant under r 11.7 — when there may be evidence disputing the primary facts relied upon by the plaintiff — difficult questions can arise about the extent to which the court must be satisfied the case falls within the provisions of Sch 6 . This is particularly so having regard to the circumstance that the criteria in the rule differ between matters that involve several elements of the proposed cause of action, for example, Sch 6(c) and others where it is merely necessary to show that the alleged liability is of a particular type or involves a particular kind of property, for example, Sch 6(p), (q) and (r): Seaconsar Far East Ltd v Bank Markazi Jomhouri Islami Iran [1994] 1 AC 438 at 453; [1993] 4 All ER 456 . Under the former Rules, and notwithstanding that they differed in some respects from the provisions in the English Rules, it was accepted that the court had to be satisfied there was a good arguable case that the qualifying conditions of Sch 6 had been complied with: LEP International Pty Ltd v Atlanttraffıc Express Services Inc (1987) 10 NSWLR 614; (1989) 63 ALJR 26 ; Vitkovice Horni a Hutni Tezirstvo v Korner [1951] AC 869; [1951] 2 All ER 334 ; Seaconsar Far East , above, AC at 453. A similar position had been applied under the present rules, even though there is no express requirement, either in r 11.4 or r 11.7 , that the court be “satisfied” that the qualifying conditions have been made out. The appropriate standard of satisfaction was that of the “good arguable case”: Hyde v Agar (1998) 45 NSWLR 487 at 503–6; BC9805415 ; Bank of America v Bank of New York (1995) ATPR ¶41-390, and under that criterion, the strength of the evidence required to show that there is sufficient “arguable” or “prima facie” compliance with the qualifying conditions was important: Hyde v Agar , above, at 503–6; Pendal Nominees Pty Ltd v M & A Investments Pty Ltd (1989) 18 NSWLR 383 ; Goliath Portland Cement Co Ltd v Bengtell (1994) 33 NSWLR 414; BC9405151 ; Williams v Lips-Heerlen BV (NSWSC, Giles J, 1 November 1991, unreported, BC9101462); and on appeal CE Heath Underwriting & Insurance (Aust) Pty Ltd v Barden (NSWSC, Rolfe J, 50132/93, 19 October 1994, unreported, BC9403144); News Corp Ltd v Lenfest Communications Inc (1996) 21 ACSR 553; BC9604395 (prima facie or arguable case is sufficient). However, in Agar v Hyde (2000) 201 CLR 552; 173 ALR 665; [2000] HCA 41; BC200004311 at [51], [56]–[61] , a majority of the High Court said that the degree of satisfaction required was the same as that required to survive an ordinary application for summary judgment. The majority held that Bank of America v Bank of New York (1995) ATPR ¶41-390 should be overruled to the extent that it required any greater satisfaction about the strength of the plaintiff’s claim.

level.toc-caption: [11.4.15] Discretion to refuse leave to proceed

p.text: Legislation cited in [11.4.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 Sch 6.

heading.title: Discretion to refuse leave to proceed

p.text: Many of the different criteria for leave in Sch 6 are confined to classification of the claim according to the nature of the claim or the property affected. Neither expressly nor impliedly do they require any assessment of the merits of claims in determining whether they fall within the scope of the rule. Nevertheless, even if it is established that the case does fall within the provisions of Sch 6, it is still a matter of discretion whether leave should be given or, alternatively, service set aside: Hyde v Agar (1998) 45 NSWLR 487; BC9805415 ; Esanda Finance Corp Ltd v Wordplex Information Systems Ltd (1990) 19 NSWLR 146 at 154–5 ; Société Generale de Paris v Dreyfus Bros (1887) 37 Ch D 215 ; Vitkovice Horni a Hutni Tezirstvo v Korner [1951] AC 869; [1951] 2 All ER 334 ; The Hagen [1908] P 189 ; Maclaine Watson & Co Private Ltd v Bing Chen [1983] 1 NSWLR 163. In the exercise of that discretion, the court may consider the apparent merits of the plaintiff's case, but leave should not be refused if the claim is sufficiently arguable to survive an application for summary judgment or a strike out application: Agar v Hyde (2000) 201 CLR 552; 173 ALR 665; [2000] HCA 41; BC200004311 at [51], [56]–[61] , overruling Bank of America v Bank of New York (1995) ATPR ¶41-390. The fact that a limitation period has expired would ordinarily provide sufficient reason to refuse leave: Bernstein v Jackson [1982] 2 All ER 806; [1982] 1 WLR 1082; Leal v Dunlop Bio-processes International Ltd [1984] 2 All ER 207 ; Hyde v Agar (NSWSC, Grove J, 22 July 1996, unreported, BC9603103). Again, leave is liable to be set aside if there has not been full and frank disclosure upon an ex parte application for leave: Sheldon Pallet Manufacturing Co Pty Ltd v New Zealand Forest Products [1975] 1 NSWLR 141; Amalgamated Chemicals Ltd v Montedison Spa (NSWSC, Roden J, No 9399/84, 26 August 1985, unreported, BC8500583). Where the defendant does not protest within a reasonable time of service, that factor in itself may be a reason why leave should be granted: Samarni v Williams [1980] 2 NSWLR 389. Subject to the application of the principle of forum non conveniens, it is not appropriate to regard the jurisdiction conferred by Sch 6 as “exorbitant” and to refuse leave to proceed on the basis of a judicial perception of international “comity”: Hyde v Agar (1998) 45 NSWLR 487; BC9805415 at 503–6 , disapproving Amin Rasheed Shipping Corp v Kuwait Insurance Co [1984] AC 50 at 65; [1983] 2 All ER 884 at 891 per Lord Diplock; Vitkovice Horni , above; Tyne Improvement Cmrs v Armement Anversois S/A (The Brabo) [1949] AC 326 at 350; [1949] 1 All ER 294 ; Société Generale , above.
Legislation cited in [11.4.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 11.7(2).
The Supreme Court may be an “inappropriate” forum (or a “clearly inappropriate forum”) for the proceedings:

if litigation between the same parties and involving the same subject matter is already pending in another forum: Henry v Henry (1996) 185 CLR 571; 135 ALR 564; [1995] HCA 64; BC9601211 ; cf Rocklea Spinning Mills Pty Ltd v Consolidated Trading Corp [1995] 2 VR 181 ;

if the substance of the action involves foreign conduct and is subject to foreign law: Voth v Manildra Flour Mills Pty Ltd (1990) 171 CLR 538; 97 ALR 124; 65 ALJR 83; BC9002894 (tort action — advice by foreign professional adviser — tax treatment of interest payments by foreign importer — stay granted); (but not merely because the parties’ dispute is subject to foreign law: Regie National des Usines Renault SA v Zhang (2002) 210 CLR 491; 187 ALR 1; [2002] HCA 10; BC200200802 at [81] );

if the proceedings are subject to, and the claim is futile under the relevant, substantive foreign law: Garsec Pty Ltd v His Majesty Sultan of Brunei [2008] NSWCA 211; BC200807965 (sovereign immunity under foreign law);

even though the relief claimed is not available in any foreign proceedings: Voth v Manildra Flour Mills Pty Ltd (1990) 171 CLR 538 at 558-9; 97 ALR 124; 65 ALJR 83; BC9002894 . (The fact that a particular cause of action is only available in the local forum is always relevant to any assessment of the appropriateness of that forum: Best Australia Ltd v Aquagas Marketing Pty Ltd (1988) 83 ALR 217 at 223–34; 12 IPR 143; (1988) AIPC 90-513 (infringement of Australian patent unable to be litigated outside Australia). Views may reasonably differ about the significance, in any particular case, of substantive and procedural limitations and defences that would preclude the local plaintiff’s success in any foreign proceedings: see Garsec Pty Ltd v His Majesty Sultan of Brunei [2008] NSWCA 211; BC200807965 at [11]-[24] and compare [146]-[148].)
if the parties have contractually agreed upon a foreign forum: see [s 67.30].
Other examples, where the local jurisdiction has been held not to be an “inappropriate” forum (or a “clearly inappropriate forum”) for the proceedings include:

where the plaintiff is a local resident whose medical condition prevents convenient foreign travel: Mody v South Seas Cruises Ltd [2008] NSWSC 1281; BC200810423 (NSW resident injured on holiday in Fiji — medical condition inhibiting attendance at trial in Fiji — NSW forum not “clearly inappropriate”)

where the proceedings concern real property within the jurisdiction and the application of uncontentious principles of foreign law: Murakami v Wiryadi (2010) 268 ALR 377; [2010] NSWCA 7; BC201000540 (testator’s real estate interests subject to unresolved dispute in foreign divorce proceedings — uncontentious foreign law).

The evidence in support of the application for leave should be given by a person who has personal knowledge of the relevant matters so that there is proper evidence on which the exercise of discretion to grant or refuse leave can be made (Stanley Kerr Holdings Pty Ltd v Gibor Textile Enterprises Ltd [1978] 2 NSWLR 372 at 375), although the court may not require strict proof of all the matters relied upon: Challenor v Douglas [1983] 2 NSWLR 405.

Consideration should be given to supporting an application for leave under this rule with evidence of advice obtained from the International Civil Procedures section of the Attorney-General's Department, Robert Garran offices, National Circuit, Barton, ACT, 2600, as to the most appropriate form of service in the country concerned of service in the manner proposed. (This requirement is made in relation to service of Federal Court originating process: see Federal Court Practice Note 13 of 28 April 1997).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 11.5] r 11.5 Service of documents other than originating process (cf SCR Part 10, rule 3)

leg:heading.title: Service of documents other than originating process (cf SCR Part 10, rule 3)

p.text: Service outside Australia of a document other than originating process is valid only if it is effected pursuant to the leave of the Supreme Court or is subsequently confirmed by the Supreme Court.
Legislation cited in [11.5.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 24.3.
(CTH) Bankruptcy Act 1966 s 81.

This rule applies to a subpoena for the production of documents and authorises the court to grant leave for service of a subpoena outside Australia, but it does not authorise a grant of leave for such service in another country inconsistently with established criteria of international law with regard to comity: Arhill Pty Ltd v General Terminal Co Pty Ltd (1990) 23 NSWLR 545 at 550, 553 ; Re Tucker; Ex parte Tucker [1988] 1 All ER 603; [1988] 2 WLR 748. Despite the amplitude of the power implicit in the present rule, the court will not usually issue a subpoena to a person (whether foreigner or Australian citizen) who is outside the jurisdiction. Generally, the utility of such a subpoena, in the sense of the court’s ability to sanction non-compliance, will be questionable and there will be other means by which the evidence or information sought may be pursued — including taking evidence on commission in accordance with UCPR r 24.3 : Arhill Pty Ltd v General Terminal Co Pty Ltd, aboveat 551, 553–555 ; Kuwait Asia Bank EC v National Mutual Life Nominees Ltd [1990] 3 All ER 404; [1990] 3 WLR 297; Mackinnon v Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corp [1986] Ch 482 ; Southwell v Maladina (2002) 194 ALR 51; [2002] FCA 802; BC200204757 (examination under s 81 of the Bankruptcy Act 1966 — order refused). Neither will it be appropriate to order (or confirm) substituted service within the jurisdiction: Sweeney v Howard [2007] NSWSC 262; BC200701916 ; Laurie v Carroll (1958) 98 CLR 310 at 323; 32 ALJR 7 . An order under this rule granting leave for service of a subpoena outside Australia may be set aside: Arhill Pty Ltd v General Terminal Co Pty Ltd, aboveat 551 ; Kuwait Asia Bank EC v National Mutual Life Nominees Ltd, , above,All ER at 416; WLR at 310.
Legislation cited in [11.5.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Service and Execution of Process Act 1992.
(CTH) Corporations Act 2001 s 596A.

Because an order for examination of a former director of a company under s 541 of the Companies (NSW) Code was a "writ (other than a writ of summons) notice decree or other process" within the meaning of s 14 of the Service and Execution of Process Act 1901 (Cth), such an order could be served in another state and no leave pursuant to this rule or otherwise was necessary: Re Austral Oil Estates Ltd (in liq) (1986) 7 NSWLR 440; 86 FLR 247; BC8600466 . See now the Service and Execution of Process Act 1992 (Cth) and [15,800]. Leave to serve outside Australia an examination summons under Corporations Act 2001 s 596A may be given under this rule on the basis that the summons itself (as distinct from the application for the summons) is not an originating process: Application of Robert William Whitton [2007] NSWSC 606; BC200704487 at [4]–[10] per White J (leave given to serve summons in USA). Leave to serve examination summonses in the United Kingdom (McGrath as Liquidators of HIH Insurance Ltd [2008] NSWSC 881; BC200807669 per Barrett J) and Hong Kong (McGrath as Liquidators of HIH Insurance Ltd [2008] NSWSC 780; BC200806878 per Barrett J) have been given under this rule.

level.toc-caption: [11.5.15] Service of a letter of request

p.text: Legislation cited in [11.5.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Corporations Act 2001 s 581(4).

heading.title: Service of a letter of request

p.text: The court may authorise that a letter of request be directed to a foreign court for assistance: see Evidence on Commission Act 1995 s 6(1)(c); Corporations Act 2001 s 581(4) . General provisions relating to the issue of letters of request are dealt with in [24.5.5]–[24.5.20] . Examples of situations where letters of request were issued under Corporations Act 2001 s 581(4) include: McGrath as Liquidators of HIH Insurance Ltd [2008] NSWSC 780; BC200806878 per Barrett J (letter of request to the High Court of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region); McGrath as Liquidators of HIH Insurance Ltd [2008] NSWSC 881; BC200807669 per Barrett J (a similar letter of request to the High Court of Justice of England and Wales).
An interlocutory injunction may be the subject of leave for foreign service under the present rule: see Bulldogs Rugby League Club Ltd v Williams [2008] NSWSC 822; BC200807132 at [77] .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 11.6] r 11.6 Mode of service (cf SCR Part 10, rule 5)

leg:heading.title: Mode of service (cf SCR Part 10, rule 5)

p.text: A document to be served outside Australia need not be personally served on a person so long as it is served on the person in accordance with the law of the country in which service is effected.

level.toc-caption: [11.6.5] Service of originating process in a foreign country

heading.title: Service of originating process in a foreign country

p.text: This rule permits service of originating process in a foreign country to be effected in accordance with the requirement of that country's law for service of such process, even though personal service would be required if the document was served in Australia: BP Exploration Co (Libya) Ltd v Hunt [1980] 1 NSWLR 496 at 501–2; Williams v Lips-Heerlen BV (NSWSC, Giles J, 1 November 1991, unreported, BC9101462).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 11.7] r 11.7 Setting aside originating process served outside Australia (cf SCR Part 10, rule 6A)

leg:heading.title: Setting aside originating process served outside Australia (cf SCR Part 10, rule 6A)

p.text: The Supreme Court may make an order of a kind referred to in rule 12.11 (Setting aside originating process etc) on application by a defendant on whom originating process is served outside Australia.
Without limiting subrule (1), the Supreme Court may make an order under this rule:
on the ground that the service of the originating process is not authorised by these rules, or
on the ground that the court is an inappropriate forum for the trial of the proceedings.

level.toc-caption: [11.7.5] Service of originating process not authorised by the rules

p.text: Legislation cited in [11.7.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 11.2, 11.4.

heading.title: Service of originating process not authorised by the rules

p.text: Originating process may be served outside Australia in any of the 23 different categories of circumstances referred to in Sch 6: UCPR 11.2 . Those circumstances are discussed in the notes [11.2.5]–[11.2 75] . A very general description of those circumstances is that foreign service is authorised if the proceedings (i) involve a cause of action, conduct or damage that occurred or accrued within NSW, (ii) a legal relationship or property that is subject to the law of NSW or (iii) claim relief against a person who is ordinarily subject to the law of NSW.

The threshold issue of authority for foreign service of the originating process raises a similar question to one of the issues that arises in an application for leave to proceed under UCPR 11.4 . That question is degree of satisfaction required that the proceedings fall within one or other of the categories of authorised service. As noted in [11.4.10] , the Plaintiff does not have to establish a “prima facie” or “good arguable” case. It is sufficient for a plaintiff to satisfy the court that there is a real issue to be determined (that assessment being made on essentially the same basis as a defendant’s application for summary judgment): see Agar v Hyde (2000) 201 CLR 552; 173 ALR 665; [2000] HCA 41; BC200004311 and [13.1.5]–[13.1.10] .
Legislation cited in [11.7.7] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 11.4, r 11.7(2), subr 11.7(2)(b), r 12.11, Sch 6.

The introductory words in r 11.7(2) refer to the more general discretionary powers conferred by UCPR r 12.11 . They suggest that, on an application to set aside service of originating process under this rule, as on an application for leave to proceed under r 11.4 , the court has a flexible residual discretion that is exercisable having regard to all the circumstances of the case: Esanda Finance Corp Ltd v Wordplex Information Systems Ltd (1990) 19 NSWLR 146 at 154–5; 99 FLR 40 . Theoretically that discretion suggests that even though a plaintiff does not have to establish they have an arguable case on the merits, the apparent strength or weakness of the claimed authority to serve out of the jurisdiction remains a relevant consideration: Australian Iron & Steel Pty Ltd v Jumbo Scheepvaart Maatschappij (Curacao) NV (1988) 14 NSWLR 507 ; Pendal Nominees Pty Ltd v M & A Investments Pty Ltd (1989) 18 NSWLR 383 ; Williams v Lips-Heerlen BV (NSWSC, Giles J, 1 November 1991, unreported, BC9101462), However, the true position is more likely to be that if the court is satisfied (to the extent required above) that foreign service of the originating process was authorised, there is in fact little scope to set aside foreign service, other than on the ground that the court is an “inappropriate forum” under subr 11.7(2)(b) : Garsec Pty Ltd v His Majesty Sultan of Brunei [2008] NSWCA 211; BC200807965 at [54]-[59] ; see Clark v Auspicious Yacht Sales Pty Ltd [2006] NSWSC 37; BC200600464 at [24] (service set aside — pleading failed to allege a cause of action and the requirements of UCPR Sch 6 were not met); and see also [11.4.15] .

The principles and criteria stated in Voth v Manildra Flour Mills Pty Ltd (1990) 171 CLR 538; 97 ALR 124; 65 ALJR 83; BC9002894 apply to the exercise of the discretion conferred by this rule: see Regie National des Usines Renault SA v Zhang (2002) 210 CLR 491 at [25]; 187 ALR 1; 23 NSWCCR 207; [2002] HCA 10; BC200200802 at [23]–[25] ; Garsec Pty Ltd v His Majesty Sultan of Brunei [2008] NSWCA 211; BC200807965 at [59] .
The application of the “clearly inappropriate forum” test is discussed further, with examples of its application, in [s 67.55] and [11.4.20] .

In assessing whether the local forum is inappropriate and, in particular, questions of convenience to the parties, the court should be mindful of the relative ease of international travel, the use which can be made of written statements and the possible use of video technology for the cross-examination of witnesses: CE Heath Underwriting & Insurance (Aust) Pty Ltd v Barden (NSWSC, Rolfe J, 50132/93, 19 October 1994, unreported, BC9403144); Sunbeam Corp Ltd v MTI Qualos Pty Ltd (NSWSC, Giles CJ Comm Div, 14 December 1995, unreported, BC9506830).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 11.8] r 11.8 Operation of Commonwealth laws (cf SCR Part 10, rule 6)

leg:heading.title: Operation of Commonwealth laws (cf SCR Part 10, rule 6)

p.text: This Part does not require the leave of the Supreme Court for any service or other thing that may be effected or done under any law of the Commonwealth, the Hague Convention or Part 11A .
Part 11A deals with service of judicial documents under the Hague Convention.
[r 11.8 am Amendment 27 of 2009 Sch 1[7], [8], effective 10 July 2009]

A similar version of the present rule was held not to be inconsistent with the Service and Execution of Process Act 1901 (see now the Service and Execution of Process Act 1992 (Cth)) in Flaherty v Girgis (1985) 4 NSWLR 248; 63 ALR 466 .
